facts.text: Two persons named Mahomedali Habib and Sakerkhanoo Mahomedali Habib carried on business as merchants and pucca adatias in bullion and companyton at Bombay under the name Habib Sons.

anchor.surface_text: Two persons named Mahomedali Habib and Sakerkhanoo Mahomedali Habib used to carry on business as merchants and pucca adatias in bullion and companyton at Bombay under the name and style of Habib Sons.

facts.text: Habib Sons instituted Summary Suit No 233 of 1948 in the Bombay City Civil Court against Jugalkishore Saraf for Rs. 7,113-7-0 with interest.

anchor.surface_text: In 1948 that firm instituted a suit in the Bombay City Civil Court, being Summary Suit No 233 of 1948, against the present appellant Juga-lkishore Saraf, a Hindu inhabitant carrying on business at Bombay, for the recovery of Rs. 7,113-7-0 with interest at 6 per cent. per annum said to be due by him to the firm in respect of certain transactions in gold and silver effected by the firm as pucca adatias.

facts.text: On 7th February 1949, a document was executed whereby Habib Sons agreed to transfer all book and other debts due to them in connection with their business in Bombay to Messrs Raw Cotton Company Limited.

anchor.surface_text: On the 7th February,. 1949 when that summary suit was still pending a document was executed whereby it was agreed that the two partners would transfer and Messrs Raw Cotton Company, Limited,  hereinafter called the respondent companypany  1372 would accept the transfer of, inter alia, all book and other debts due to them in companynection with their business in Bombay and full benefit of all securities for the debts and all other property to which they were entitled in companynection with the said business.

facts.text: Raw Cotton Company did not take steps under O. XXII r. 10 CPC to get substituted as plaintiffs in the suit.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent companypany did number take steps under 0. XXII, r. 10 of the Code of Civil Procedure to get themselves substituted as plaintiffs in the place and stead of Habib Sons, the plaintiffs on record, but allowed the suit to be companytinued in the name of the original plaintiffs.

facts.text: The two partners of Habib Sons migrated from India to Pakistan and their properties vested in the Custodian of Evacuee Property.

anchor.surface_text: Evidently, the two partners migrated from India to Pakistan and their properties vested in the Custodian of Evacuee Property.

facts.text: On 15th December 1949, a decree was passed in the summary suit for Rs. 8,428-7-0 in favour of Habib Sons.

anchor.surface_text: On the 15th December 1949 a decree was passed in the summary suit for the sum of Rs. 8,018-7-0 for the debt and interest and the sum of Rs. 410 for companyts of the suit, aggregating to Rs. 8,428-7-0, and for further interest at 4 per cent. per annum from the date of the decree until payment.

facts.text: On 2nd August 1950, the Additional Custodian confirmed the transfer of business of Habib Sons to Raw Cotton Company.

anchor.surface_text: On the 11th December 1950 the Custodian of Evacuee Property, Bombay, informed the respondent companypany that by an order made on the 2nd August 1950 the Additional Custodian of Evacuee Property had companyfirmed the transaction of transfer of the business of Habib Sons to the respondent companypany.

facts.text: On 25th April 1951, Raw Cotton Company presented an application for execution under O. XXI r.11 CPC.

anchor.surface_text: On or about the 25th April, 1951 the respondent companypany presented before the Bombay City Civil Court a tabular statement purporting to be an application for execution under Order XXI,rule 11 of the Code of Civil Procedure.

facts.text: In the execution application, respondent prayed to be declared assignees of the decree based on deed dated 7th February 1949 confirmed by Custodian.

anchor.surface_text: In the last companyumn of the tabular statement, under the heading The mode in which the assistance of the Court is required, the respondent companypany prayed that the Court be pleased to declare the Applicants the assignees of the decree as the decrement debt along with other debts bad been transferred by the plaintiffs to the Applicants by a deed of assignment dated the 7th February 1949 which was companyfirmed by the Custodian of Evacuee Property, Bombay, and order them to be substituted for the plaintiffs.

facts.text: On 10th May 1951, City Civil Court issued notice under O. XXI r.16 to Habib Sons and Jugalkishore Saraf.

anchor.surface_text: On the 10th May 1951 the Bombay City Civil Court issued a numberice under Order XXI, rule 16 of the Code to Habib Sons, who were the decree-holders on record, and Jugalkishore Saraf, who was the defendant judgment-debtor, requiring them to show cause why the decree passed in the suit on the 15th December 1949 in favour of the plaintiffs and by them transferred to the respondent companypany, should number be executed by the said transferees against the said defendant judgment-debtor.

facts.text: Jugalkishore Saraf denied execution of the document and that it transferred the decree.

anchor.surface_text: The defendant judgment-debtor showed cause by filing an affidavit affirmed by him on the 15th June 1951. Amongst other things, he denied that the document in question had been executed or that the document transferred the decree to the respondent companypany.

facts.text: Executing court proved execution of document by attesting witness and accepted it, rejected contention on transfer of decree, made notice absolute.

anchor.surface_text: The matter was tried on evidence and the execution of the document was proved by the evidence of an attesting witness which has been accepted by the executing Court. The executing Court, however, rejected the second companytention and made the numberice absolute with companyts and gave leave to the respondent companypany to execute the decree against the judgment-debtor.

facts.text: Judgment-debtor appealed to High Court, appeal heard by Dixit J., dismissed affirming executing court.

anchor.surface_text: The judgment-debtor filed an appeal before the High Court. The appeal was heard by Dixit, J. Before him the execution of the document was number challenged and numberhing further need be said about that. The only substan- tial question raised wag whether the respondent companypany were the transferees of the decree within the meaning of Order XXI, rule 16.

facts.text: Letters Patent Appeal before High Court dismissed by Chagla CJ and Shah J.

anchor.surface_text: The judgment-debtor preferred a Letters Patent Appeal before the High Court which was dismissed by Chagla, J., and Shah, J., following the two earlier decisions mentioned above.

facts.text: High Court granted certificate under Art 133(1)(c) for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: They, however,  1  1877 I.L.R. 11 Bom. 506. I.L.R. 1946 Bom. 276. 1374 granted, under article 133  1   c  of the Constitution, a certificate of fitness for appeal to this Court.

facts.text: Appeal is Civil Appeal No. 212 of 1954 in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 212 of 1954. Appeal from the Judgment and Decree dated the 10th day of November 1953 of the High Court of Judicature at Bombay in Appeal No. 8 of 1953 under the Letters Patent,

facts.text: High Court judgment dated 10th November 1953 in Appeal No. 8 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the Judgment and Decree dated the 10th day of November 1953 of the High Court of Judicature at Bombay in Appeal No. 8 of 1953 under the Letters Patent, against the decree dated the 23rd day of September 1952 of the said High Court in Appeal No. 67 of 1952 from Original Decree arising out of Order dated the 20th November 1951 of the City Civil Court, Bombay, in Summary Suit No. 233 of 1948.

facts.text: Executing court order dated 20th November 1951.

anchor.surface_text: against the decree dated the 23rd day of September 1952 of the said High Court in Appeal No. 67 of 1952 from Original Decree arising out of Order dated the 20th November 1951 of the City Civil Court, Bombay, in Summary Suit No. 233 of 1948.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgments delivered on March 7, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: 1955. March 7. The following Judgments were delivered. DAS J.-The facts leading up to this appeal are few and simple.

facts.text: In High Court appeal before Dixit J., execution of document not challenged.

anchor.surface_text: Before him the execution of the document was number challenged and numberhing further need be said about that.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds document did not transfer the decree by assignment in writing under O.XXI r.16.

anchor.surface_text: In my judgment the decree was number transferred or agreed to be transferred to the respondent companypany by the document under companysideration and the latter cannot claim to be transferees of the decree by an assignment in writing as companytemplated by Order XXI, rule 16.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds respondent entitled to execute under s.146 CPC as claiming under decree-holder.

anchor.surface_text: In my opinion, the respondent companypany are entitled under section 146 to make the application for execution which the original decree- holders companyld do.

facts.text: Appeal dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The result, therefore, is that this appeal must be dismissed with companyts.

Before him the execution of the document was not challenged and nothing further need be said about that. The only substantial question raised was whether the respondent company were the transferees of the decree within the meaning of Order XXI, rule 16.

arguments.claim: Respondent company transferees under O.XXI r.16 by equitable assignment of future decree via document.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judge answered the question in the affirmative on the authority of the decisions of the Bombay High Court in Purmananddas Jivandas v. Vallabdas Wallji and in Chimanlal Hargovinddas v. Ghulamnabi and affirming the order of the executing Court dismissed the appeal.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ause why the decree passed in the suit on the 15th December 1949 in favour of the plaintiffs and by them transferred to the respondent companypany, sh

arguments.court_reasoning: SC applied literal construction; document predates decree, no specific agreement to transfer future decree; equitable principle does not create assignment in writing.

arguments.claim: Strict construction of O.XXI r.16 shows no assignment as document before decree.

anchor.surface_text: The principal question urged before us is as to whether the respondent company can claim to be the transferees of the decree within the meaning of Order XXI, rule 16 of the Code of Civil Procedure... The cardinal rule of construction of statutes is to read the statute literally, that is by giving to the words used by the legislature their ordinary, natural and grammatical meaning.

arguments.claim: Document does not transfer or agree to transfer future decree; covers only existing properties/debts under s.8 TPA.

anchor.surface_text: Reference may also be made to the provisions of the Transfer of Property Act. Under section 8 of that Act the transfer of property passes to the transferee all the interest which the transferor is then capable of passing in the property... There was then no decree in existence and, therefore, the transferors could not then pass any interest in the non-existing decree.

arguments.claim: No equitable assignment as no agreement to transfer future decree; equity does not relate back to create assignment in writing under O.XXI r.16.

anchor.surface_text: It is quite true that a deed which professes to convey property which is not in existence at the time is as a conveyance void at law... equity, treating as done that which ought to be done, fastens upon that property... In order, therefore, to test the propriety of the application of this equitable principle... we have to enquire whether there was here any agreement between the parties to transfer the decree.

arguments.claim: Not transferees by operation of law under O.XXI r.16 as document does not cover decree and equitable principle not applicable.

anchor.surface_text: the phrase by operation of law... transfers by operation of law will be found to be brought about by the operation of statutory law... As, however, I have held that that document did not cover the decree, there was no room for the application of the equitable principle.

arguments.claim: Respondent entitled to execute under s.146 CPC as persons claiming under decree-holders (owners of debt, transferors as benamidars).

anchor.surface_text: In my opinion, the respondent company are entitled under section 146 to make the application for execution which the original decree-holders could do... the position of the transferors, vis-a-vis the respondent company, was nothing more than that of benamidars for the respondent company.

arguments.claim: Execution application defective under O.XXI r.11 as no specification of mode of assistance required.

anchor.surface_text: Learned Counsel for the appellant contends that the application for execution was defective in that although it purported to be an application for execution under Order XXI, rule 11, it did not comply with the requirements.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: .L.R. 111. 1378 passed was also included in this document. The reasoning appears to be this Clause 1

arguments.court_reasoning: No objection taken before executing court; another tabular statement presented specifying mode.

holdings.text: The decree was not transferred or agreed to be transferred to the respondent company by the document under consideration and the latter cannot claim to be transferees of the decree by an assignment in writing as contemplated by Order XXI, rule 16.

anchor.surface_text: In my judgment the decree was number transferred or agreed to be transferred to the respondent companypany by the document under companysideration and the latter cannot claim to be transferees of the decree by an assignment in writing as companytemplated by Order XXI, rule 16.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Literal construction of O.XXI r.16 requires transfer after decree passed; document executed before decree; no specific mention of suit or future decree; s.8 TPA passes only existing interests.

holdings.text: There was no agreement between the parties to transfer the decree to be passed in the then pending suit, so equitable principle of assignment of future property does not apply to constitute assignment under O.XXI r.16.

anchor.surface_text: In order, therefore, to test the propriety of the application of this equitable principle to the facts of the present case we have to enquire whether there was here any agreement between the parties to transfer the decree to be passed in the then pending suit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Document transfers existing book debts and properties entitled at time; no mention of pending suit or future decree; equity fastens only if agreement to transfer future property exists.

holdings.text: The respondent company did not become transferees of the decree by operation of law within the meaning of Order XXI, rule 16.

anchor.surface_text: As, however, I have held that that document did number companyer the decree, there was numberroom for the application of the equitable principle.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No coverage of decree in document; equitable principle inapplicable without agreement; operation of law broadly interpreted but not triggered here.

holdings.text: The respondent company are entitled under section 146 CPC to make the application for execution which the original decree-holders could do.

anchor.surface_text: In my opinion, the respondent companypany are entitled under section 146 to make the application for execution which the original decree- holders companyld do.

holdings.reasoning_summary: O.XXI r.16 does not preclude s.146; respondents claim under decree-holders as owners of underlying debt post-transfer; original holders became benamidars.

holdings.text: The respondent company are persons claiming under the decree-holder within section 146 CPC.

anchor.surface_text: There are two questions to be companysidered before the section may be applied, namely,  1  whether the Code otherwise provides and  2  whether the respondent companypany can be said to be persons claiming under the decree-holder.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Transfer of debt carries remedies; respondents real owners of decree for recovery of transferred debt; decree-holders on record acted as benamidars.

holdings.text: The application for execution was not defective under Order XXI, rule 11.

anchor.surface_text: Learned Counsel for the appellant companytends that the application for execution was defective in that although it purported to be an application for execution under Order XXI, rule 1 1, it did number companyply with the requirements

holdings.reasoning_summary: No objection raised before executing court; another compliant tabular statement presented; waiver by conduct.

holdings.text: Transfer by operation of law under O.XXI r.16 includes any passing of interest by force of law, statutory or otherwise, not confined to death, insolvency or succession.

anchor.surface_text: The result of the authorities appears to me to be that if by reason of any provision of law, statutory or otherwise, interest in property passes from one person to another there is a transfer of the property by operation of law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Survey of precedents; broad interpretation includes court sales, equitable principles, personal laws; distinguishes narrow views.

justification_sets.label: Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support
Equitable Assignment of Future Property support
Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support
